title: A review on the state of the biodiversity knowledge on Iran's southern seas: introducing a methodology to evaluate the validity of the reported cases

abstract: High maritime activities in the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman as the major waterways for oil and gas transport and the lack of a documented database on total taxa diversity require greater attention for the biodiversity of these environments. The available marine biodiversity data in Iran are sparse and abandoned on libraries' shelves and, as such, accessing relevant and reliable current information about the status of Iranian southern seas biodiversity is challenging. Therefore, there is an urgent need to extract, standardize, and evaluate these biodiversity data. A comprehensive review of the available biodiversity data on the Iranian southern seas provided an estimate about the species diversity and highlighted the amount of reliable biodiversity data, research gaps, and required information for the lesser-known areas. In the present review, the available biodiversity data records of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman under Iranian ownership was extracted from non-database information sources (books, theses, research reports, and articles) and open-access database portals, such as the Ocean Biogeographic Information System (OBIS), Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF, https://doi.org/10.15468/dl.jm7hat), and those museum collections with online portal data collection search facilities. In total, 59,745 biodiversity records were extracted from all information sources. After data standardization based on the OBIS data scheme (Darwin core format), eight criteria with 29 sub-criteria were considered and scored to measure the validity of each record. Consequently, the presence of 3364 valid species (more than twice the number predicted earlier for the total species diversity) was reported for the study area. Describing new species shows an increasing trend, as most of the 80 new species until the beginning of 2018 were described recently. Mollusca phylum had the most amount of synonymy in non-database information sources. The results show that some marine taxa have been ignored in previous studies and the focus was on a certain group of organisms. Multi-criteria scoring analysis shows that 6% of the extracted biodiversity data for non-database information sources have 75-100% credit (valid), 70% have 50-75% credit (semi-valid), 23. 4% have 25-50% credit (a little valid), and 0.9% have 0-25% credit (invalid). On the other hand, OBIS data extracted for Iran do not have invalid data due to its good data quality control, but 58 and 20% of its extracted data are semi-valid and valid, respectively. We believe that all of the eight mentioned criteria are required for reporting biodiversity data, and our proposed weighting system helps different users who need to know how reliable is the published data.

body_text.text: Knowing how many species that inhabit the seas and oceans of the world is among the most fundamental questions in science (Mora et al. 2011) . Based on the information provided by the Catalog of Life (Roskov et al. 2016) , 1.64 million species have been described on Earth. In marine realms, about 226,000 eukaryotic species mostly described belong to the last decade and 58,000 to 72,000 species were collected but not described by taxonomists (Appeltans et al. 2012) . It was stated Communicated by P. Martinez Arbizu by Bouchet and Duarte (2006) that 1300 to 1500 new species were described per year. After 2011, different predictions were expressed for the biological diversity of existing marine species, which is in the range of at least 300,000 to more than two million species (Costello et al. 2012; Appeltans et al. 2012; Mora et al. 2011) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The growth rate of marine biodiversity knowledge among Indian Ocean countries is not uniform, which is due to the lack of human, institutional, and technical capabilities. Data from Middle East marine environments are scarce and limited to some specific taxa (Wafar et al. 2011) . The temperate waters of the northern hemisphere are the best-known regions of marine biodiversity (Bouchet and Duarte 2006) . In the Western Indian Ocean, published information on the Middle East marine environments (the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden, the Arabian Sea, the Gulf of Oman, and the Persian Gulf) are generally focused on larger taxa, while groups like sponges, ctenophores, octocorals, polychaetes, and tunicates are poorly known. On the other hand, most of the species diversity information of the region came from coral reef ecosystems, especially from the Red Sea (Richmond 2001; Wafar et al. 2011) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Establishing a robust open-access biodiversity database does not only increase the accessibility and usability of data in science, but it also vastly improves our knowledge and contributes toward more effective decisions being made for resource management (Costello and Wieczorek 2014; Palacio 2008) . Among the countries around the Indian Ocean, only India has a marine biodiversity database that is consistent (Wafar et al. 2011) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Although considerable biological data exist for Iranian marine fauna and flora, their often disparate and scattered nature, and lack of continuity between survey methodology, reporting, and species identification standards have made the resulting data vary in their quality and inefficient for providing meaningful information. These biodiversity data are scattered in non-database information sources, including research reports, scientific literatures, university theses, books, and museum archives. However, these data are not readily available from non-database sources or uncritically accepted as being true representatives of the species richness present at any given area or at any given time. If these scattered biodiversity data were integrated into an openaccess scientific database, that is accessible to different users and decision-makers, then it will enable far more informed decisions to be made with regard to biodiversity management.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Globally, a number of biodiversity databases exist that deal with Iranian marine biodiversity, such as the Ocean Biogeographic Information System (OBIS), Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF, https://doi.org/ 10.15468/dl.jm7hat), and museum collections (Table 1) . These information resources, although very useful, contain limited information for Iran due to some national limitations in international data sharing. On the other hand, they have been developed for a specific purpose and the data accuracy in species identification varied greatly among data-collection practitioners (Hammond 1995) . As suggested by Alroy (2003) , global databases yield information suitable for interpretation at a global scale. National and regional databases need to be appropriately refined to address biodiversity trends and patterns occurring at lower scales (Palacio 2008) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The creation of such infrastructure in the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman is mainly important because of their high maritime activities as the major waterways for oil and gas transport (Nadim et al. 2008) and the lack of a documented database on total taxa diversity. The most important prerequisite in this case is the extraction, digitization, and standardization of biodiversity reports from different and available information sources. Therefore, there is an urgent need to extract and standardize these biodiversity data for the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman. To fill a part of the gap, the Iranian National Institute for Oceanography and Atmospheric Science (INIOAS) was officially selected as a regional OBIS node in the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman (PEGO-OBIS, http://iobis.org/community). Then, a project (project grant number: 392-011-05) was conducted entitled BGathering, standardization/digitization and interpretation of existing biological data of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman based on OBIS scheme^. The scientific results of the project will be discussed in this review. Another part was determining the parallel research in different Iranian universities and their contribution in biodiversity data production of the study areas, as well as determining the credibility of their published data.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The extensive Iranian coastline (2250 km) (Pak and Farajzadeh 2007) compared with other coastal states of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman, along with the high maritime activities in the region due to the important oil and gas highways (Nadim et al. 2008) , are the reasons why the results of this study are also regionally significant. On the other hand, the findings of this study provide a real estimate of the species richness for part of the western Indian Ocean.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: From the national perspective, the present review helps our understanding of the Iranian southern seas taxa diversity, provides an estimate close to reality and based on available published documents (not based on predictions of Wafar et al. 2011) , and determines the amount of synonymy and invalid taxa. Finally, due to the different nature and quality of the information sources, a weighing system was proposed to evaluate the validity percent of the existing data. Research trends and gaps were also identified in the different groups of organisms, to help researchers and graduate students with their future investigations to prevent them from carrying out parallel investigations.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Iran Iran, with 750 km of coastline along the Caspian Sea and around 2250 km of coastline along the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman located in the south west of Asia, is connected to open seas via the Persian Gulf and the Strait of Hormuz (Fig. 1 ), which connect it to the Gulf of Oman and the Indian Ocean (Pak and Farajzadeh 2007) .
body_text.section: Study areas

body_text.text: The Persian Gulf, dating back to about 500 BC, is one of the oldest water passages in the world (Nadim et al. 2008) . It is a semi-enclosed sea (total area 240,000 km 2 ) located between latitudes 24 and 30°N, bordered by eight countries, with an average depth of 35 m (the deepest areas are in front of the Iranian coast, reaching from 60 m to about 100 m at the entrance to the Strait of Hormuz), with a 990-km coastline in the Iranian part. The climate of the Persian Gulf region is a typical desert and semi-desert climate, characterized by high summer temperatures and aridity throughout the year, due to its geographical situation within the subtropical high pressure belt (Barth and Khan 2008) . The high evaporation rate combined with the small connection to open oceans has led to the formation of the saline and dense water mass known as Persian Gulf Water (Nadim et al. 2008) . Fresh seawater (from the Indian Ocean) enters the gulf through the Strait of Hormuz at a salinity of 36.5 to 37 ppt and circulates in a general counter-clockwise direction with northward currents along the Iranian coasts and southward currents along the Saudi Arabian coasts. When compared with other oceans, the Persian Gulf has relatively low concentrations of nutrients, used in primary production by marine algae and higher plants (Barth and Khan 2008) . Due to the relative shallowness and water clarity of the coastal areas, the coastal sediments in the Persian Gulf support highly productive habitats, such as extensive intertidal mudflats, seagrass and algal beds, mangroves, and coral reefs. Consequently, the productivity in the Gulf is, therefore, largely sediment-based (Jones et al. 2002) .
body_text.section: The Persian Gulf

body_text.text: Geopolitically, the presence of huge oil and gas resources (57 to 66% of the known oil and 45% of natural gas reserves of the world lie in the vicinity or beneath the sea beds of the Persian Gulf) has made the Persian Gulf one of the world's most strategic waterways in the past four to five decades. High maritime activities, along with three major battles during the past three decades, have exposed the water body to serious environmental impacts (Nadim et al. 2008 ).
body_text.section: The Persian Gulf

body_text.text: Oman Sea northern coastlines consist of the sea boundary of two of Iran's four southern provinces (Fig. 1) , namely, Hormozgan and Sistan and Baluchestan. The climate in this region is more or less similar to the Indian Ocean. Due to the connection to open seas, most of Iran's main commercial ports are located on the southern coast, from which 86% of Iran's needs are imported (Pak and Farajzadeh 2007) . Table 1 List of search engines and online databases used in this study to identify publications containing biodiversity data and to extract biodiversity data The climate in the Gulf of Oman is markedly different from the climate in the Persian Gulf. While the Persian Gulf is affected mainly by the extra-tropical weather systems from the northwest, the Gulf of Oman is at the northern edge of the tropical weather systems in the Arabian Sea and Indian Ocean. This monsoon circulation produces southerly winds in the summer and strong northerlies in the winter. The Strait of Hormuz approximates a boundary between the two systems. The tidal range is large, with values greater than 1 m everywhere (Reynolds 1993) .
body_text.section: The Gulf of Oman

body_text.text: The available biodiversity distribution data were extracted from different information sources through internet searching in national/international libraries and databases (Table 1) . Global open-access databases such as OBIS, GBIF, and museum collections (German museums through the SeSam Collection Management Database and the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History) with online portal data collection search facilities (Table 1) were considered to retrieve biodiversity records distributed in the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman (Iran). However, entirely different results were acquired from these databases.
body_text.section: Data search and extraction

body_text.text: Direct observation of the library documents were undertaken to record manually biodiversity data from nondatabase information sources (books, thesis, research reports, and articles). Library documents of the ten universities, two research institutes, and other relevant executive marine authorities including Department of Environment of Iran (DOE), Iranian Fisheries Research Organizations (IFRO), Ports and Maritime Organization (PMO), and Regional Organization for the Protection of the Marine Environment (ROPME), were also directly inspected. Articles published in foreign journals were also purchased. Finally, related biodiversity data were extracted from 333 non-database information sources containing 125 university student theses, eight books, nine research reports, 191 articles, and 125 student thesis (Fig. 2) .
body_text.section: Data search and extraction

body_text.text: Data digitization to create dataset species list Froese (1996) suggested that four kinds of information form a core of biodiversity data: (1) the scientific name of an observed species, (2) the locality, (3) the time, and (4) who identified the species. Extracted biodiversity distribution data along with their accompanying information from nondatabase information sources (Fig. 2) were entered into a Microsoft Excel datasheet (ver. 2007) based on the data scheme provided by OBIS (http://old.iobis.org/node/304), which is a subset of the Darwin Core data format. According to the study goals, some additional columns were inserted into the OBIS data scheme to help us in the data evaluation process, including publisher code, type of information source (theses, articles, books, and reports), source abbreviation, taxonomic validation, identified taxonomic level, and valid species.
body_text.section: Data search and extraction

body_text.text: The spelling, synonymy, and homonymy were checked by standard taxonomic master databases proposed by Costello and Wieczorek (2014) , including the World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS Taxon Match: http://www. marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=match), the Integrated Taxonomic Information System (ITIS: http://www.itis.gov), and the Encyclopedia of Life (EOL: http://eol.org).
body_text.section: Data corrections and standardizations

body_text.text: After data standardization, eight criteria were considered mostly based on previous recommendations (citeria 1-6 in Table 2 ) for reporting useful species data (Costello and Wieczorek 2014; Costello et al. 2013; Steinke and Hanner 2011) . These criteria include museum code (MC), GPS coordinates (G), taxonomic validation (T), synonymy (S), sampling time (ST), quality of the peer review (P) in each publication containing biodiversity data, basis of record (B), and level of taxonomic identification (TL).
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: To evaluate the validity percent of each distribution record based on the weighted mean method, 29 sub-criteria (shown in Table 2 ) with various scores and coefficients were defined. These criteria were weighted based on the importance of spatio-temporal access of the specimen and the quality of species identification judged by its peer review quality. Therefore, having museum code (as also emphasized by Ponder et al. 2001) and GPS coordinates received the highest score. Subcriteria for the criterion of taxonomy levels identification (TL) were weighted based on the success rate of the researcher in identifying specimens up to the species level (Table 2) .
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: Different scores were assigned for the publications where species data are published, based on the criterion Bquality of the peer review (P)^. The highest score was assigned to the biodiversity data extracted from JCR articles listed in the Thomson Reuter's Master Journal List (http://ip-science. thomsonreuters.com/mjl). The Islamic World Science Citation Database (ISC) is a citation index, from only the Islamic Journals, established by the Ministry of Science, Research and Technology (MSRT) of Iran (http://www.isc. gov.ir). Biodiversity data extracted from ISI articles without IF and data from ISC journals received the same score (15 in Table 2 ).
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: Invalid sources refer to the articles published in invalid foreign journals, those listed by the MSRT (http://www.msrt. ir/Fa/rppc/pages/Files/InvalidForeignPublications.aspx). Unknown sources refer to articles not included in both invalid foreign journals and list of valid domestic journals provided by the MSRT (http://www.msrt.ir/fa/rppc/Pages/Files/ ValidPublications.aspx). University theses scored less than ISI and ISC articles that benefitted from international peer review processes. The research reports that did not pass the appropriate peer review process received lower scores compared to theses and articles. Assigned scores and coefficients for each sub-criterion are shown in Table 2 (numbers).
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: Finally, the weighted mean (W mean ) of eight criteria was calculated for each biodiversity distribution record with the following equation:
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: Wmean ¼ ∑KnCn ∑K
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: where n is the criterion, K is the coefficient of each criterion, and C is the assigned score for each sub-criterion. For this study, eight criteria were considered (MC, G, T, S, ST, P, B, and TL in
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: W mean ¼ 4 MC score ð Þþ3 G score ð Þþ1 T score ð Þþ1 S score ð Þþ1 ST score ð Þþ2 P score ð Þþ1 B score ð Þþ1 TL score ð Þ 14
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: The validity percent (v%) for each reported case was then calculated as:
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: v% ¼ Wmean hC Â 100
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: where hC is the highest assigned score for sub-criteria (20 in Table 2 ). Downloaded data for the study area from the OBIS database were separately evaluated based on the aforementioned equation. Hereof, the zero score was considered for data with no bibliography and a score of 20 with a coefficient of two was considered for data with bibliographic information (similar JCR articles). The calculated validity percent for all non-database distribution records (24,772) and OBIS extracted data (34,430) was categorized in four groups based on the quartile method. The method divides a range of data into four equal parts. The first group (G1) contains data with calculated validity percent in the range of 0 to 25%; these data were considered as invalid data. The second group (G2) consists of data with calculated validity percent in the range of 25 to 50%; these data were considered as a little valid data. The third group (G3), whose calculated validity percent was in the range of 50 to 75%, was assigned as semi-valid. The fourth group (G4) was considered as quite valid data, with calculated validity percent in the range of 75 to 100%.
body_text.section: Recommended criteria to evaluate the validity of each biodiversity record

body_text.text: In the present review, 24,772 cases of taxa diversity (without Aves) were extracted from 333 non-database information sources for the Iranian southern waters (Fig. 2) . The OBIS dataset contains 34,430 distribution records and GBIF contains 585 records with Aves class and 243 records without Aves for the study area. About 300 records were extracted from the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History and the SeSam Collection Management Database for the study area. In total, 59,745 distribution records were extracted from non-database and database information sources. These data had a range from microscopic organisms (i.e., phytoplankton, bacteria) to the large chordates (i.e., whales and sharks). Homogeneity was not observed between the number of non-database information sources ( Fig. 2) and their data content ( Fig. 3 ). University students with 125 theses had a significant role in producing biodiversity data. These theses produced 40.4% of the biodiversity data in the study area. A small number of books (eight books, Fig. 2 ) and ROPME research reports (seven reports, Fig. 2 ) produced more than 9.5 and 24% of the extracted data, respectively (Fig. 3) .
body_text.section: Data extraction and sources of the taxa distribution records

body_text.text: Temporally, in non-database information sources, the first recorded data for the study area originate from 1916 (Kemp 1916 ; as the Aegeon pennata). The progressive trend in biodiversity distribution records was seen in the last decade (Fig.  4) . The first record for the study area in the OBIS belongs to the Annelida (Hyalinoecia tubicola) in 1788 and biodiversity data were mostly reported from 1960 to 1970. In GBIF, the first record is a preserved species of Ulva clathrata (Chlorophyta) from 1937.
body_text.section: Data extraction and sources of the taxa distribution records

body_text.text: As shown in Fig. 5 , most of the distribution records in nondatabase information sources within the studied area belong to the Animalia (62.8%). The botanical groups containing phytoplanktons, macroalgae, mangroves, and seagrasses (Chromista and Plantae) are also well described (35.7%).
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases

body_text.text: Lack of information on Fungi, Protozoa, and Bacteria (less than 1%) is considerable. Arthropoda (26% of the extracted data) and Mollusca (13.3% of the extracted data) in kingdom Animalia and Ochrophyta (17% of the extracted data) and Myzozoa (10% of the extracted data) in kingdom Chromista were the well-studied groups. The phylum Rodophyta was better studied in kingdom Plantae. Few studies were conducted on invertebrate phyla, which are the main members in marine ecosystems, such as Echinodermata, Porifera, and Nematoda, and this is remarkable (Fig. 6) .
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases

body_text.text: The extracted data from database information sources was compared and merged with non-database information sources in this study (Fig. 8) . A total of 59,745 biodiversity cases were extracted from all information sources. In terms of quantity, the OBIS database content for Iran (34,430 records) is more than the total extracted records from non-database information sources, but its taxon diversity is lower than the data of nondatabase information sources.
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases

body_text.text: The OBIS database contains 424 species belonging to the 12 phyla and 318 genera reported for Iran (Fig. 7) , while, in total, 2920 species belonging to 44 phyla and 1900 genera were extracted from non-database sources (books, theses, research reports, and articles). Of the 2920 total species richness extracted from non-database information sources, 2651 species belong to the phyla that existed in the OBIS database ( Fig. 7) .
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases

body_text.text: Comparing OBIS datasets for the study area with nondatabase records shows that most species in the OBIS database have do not exist in non-database records. The data retrieved from GBIF contain 154 species (Fig. 7) for the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman (Iran), of which some species do not exist in non-database information sources and the OBIS. Data retrieved from museum portals exist in non-database records, the OBIS, and GBIF. Finally, 3364 species belonging to the 47 phyla and 2226 genera were extracted from nondatabase and database information sources (Fig. 8) .
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases

body_text.text: Extracted data from all information sources showed that different families within Animalia (687 families of the 933 reported families) were the favorite study groups of researchers (Fig. 8) ; however, all the families have not been uniformly studied. The results of species richness in the studied area show that the highest number of valid species belongs to the kingdoms Animalia (2441 species) and Chromista (614 species). The kingdoms Protozoa and Fungi had one recorded species and did not have any representative up to the species level (Fig. 8) . In detail, within kingdom Animalia, Arthropoda (725 species, Fig. 9 ), Chordata with 658 species, and Mollusca with 525 species are in the next ranks ( Fig. 9 ).
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases

body_text.text: How many new species have been described in previous studies?
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases

body_text.text: Until the beginning of 2018, only 80 new species have been described for the Iranian waters of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman. Most species described recently belong to the crustaceans (Table 3) . Describing only a new species of Actinobacteria (Nocardiopsis sinuspersici Hamedi et al., 2010) is considerable (Table 3) .
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases

body_text.text: The effect of the eight criteria on each biodiversity distribution record (see equation above) was investigated by a weighted mean method. The results of different validity percent calculations (Table 4) show that 81% of the extracted data from university theses are semi-valid (50 to 70% validity, G3 in Table 4 ) and just 7.6% of data are quite valid, while the average validity percent for all ISI extracted biodiversity data, which benefitted from the high quality peer review process, shows that about 20% of the data are quite valid. This means that 20% of the published biodiversity data for the study area meet the eight criteria proposed here (see Table 2 for the criteria list). However, 44.3% of the extracted data from all the ISI articles are semi-valid and 36% of the data are a little valid, that is, considerable (G3 and G2 in Table 4 ), which shows that these published data do not meet some of the eight criteria mentioned earlier. Accordingly, this was recommended during the peer review process and, to provide data with maximum validity, the eight proposed criteria need to be considered together. 1901 1905 1910 1916 1924 1930 1936 1945 1963 1968 1971 1981 1986 1994 1997 2000 2003 2006 2009 2012 Number of reported taxa year OBIS database sources other than OBIS Fig. 4 Distribution records of taxa per year that has been extracted from non-database information sources (dashed line) and the OBIS database (bold line) Fig. 5 Distribution of the extracted biodiversity data per kingdom from non-database information sources. Of the 24,772 extracted taxa, 62.8% of the data within the studied area belong to the Animalia. There were only a few reports extracted for Bacteria and Fungi. Half of the extracted data were taxonomically invalid Based on our results, 10% of the extracted data were synonymous, mostly belonging to the phylum Mollusca. The percentage of synonymy in different phyla is as shown in Fig. 10 . The validity of biodiversity data was evaluated using the newly designed method.
body_text.section: Evaluating the validity of data

body_text.text: High maritime activities in the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman as the major waterways for oil and gas transport (Nadim et al. 2008) and the lack of documented database on total taxa diversity require greater attention for the biodiversity of these environments. Although considerable biological data exist for Iranian marine fauna and flora, their often disparate and scattered nature, and lack of continuity between survey methodology, reporting, and species identification standards have made the resulting data vary in their quality and inefficient for providing meaningful information. These biodiversity data are scattered in non-database information sources, including research reports, scientific literatures, university theses, books, and museum archives. However, these data are not readily available from non-database sources or uncritically accepted as true representatives of the species richness present at any given area or at any given time. If these scattered biodiversity data are integrated into an open-access database, that is accessible to managers and decision-makers, then it will enable far more informed decisions to be made with regard to biodiversity management. The most important prerequisite in this case is the extraction and digitization of the available biodiversity data from all available information sources. The present review firstly provides a literature survey on the available biodiversity data of the study area from nondatabase information sources and then it presents information on taxa diversity and species richness resulting from the extraction of available information sources ( access databases, and museum archives). Secondly, a weighting system was proposed to evaluate the validity percent of the extracted data.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: An extensive review of the non-database information sources shows that biodiversity data of Iranian southern waters has been collected in two ways. The first is in the form of largescale research cruises conducted by national (IFRO, INIOAS) and regional institutions (ROPME). These studies provided a general overview on the biota of the study area and had less attention paid to the identification of the collected specimens to the species level. Some of these studies include studies on macrobenthic fauna (Taheri et al. 2010; Talebzadeh 1995) , macrobenthic flora (Gharanjik and Rohani Ghadikolaei 2010; Sohrabipour and Rabiei 2007) , zooplankton communities (Dorgham et al. 2013; Rabbaniha et al. 2011) , phytoplankton communities (Al-Yamani et al. 2012; Fatemi et al. 2005) , and fishes (Asadi and Dehghani 1996; Ghanbarifardi and Malek 2009; Valinassab et al. 2006) . However, the lack of a peer review process on produced data and identification of the The second group of studies passed an acceptable peer review process, including student theses and articles that more specifically studied the marine organisms of the study area. Our review shows that there is heterogeneity of studies on marine biota, since crustaceans (particularly decapods) are well studied compared to other taxa (Al-Yamani 2012; Anker et al. 2010; Corbera et al. 2005 Sari 2005a, b, 2007a, b; Naderloo and Schubart 2010; Naderloo and Türkay 2009 Naderloo et al. , 2013 Naderloo 2005; Ng et al. 2009 Ng et al. , 2011 Ng et al. , 2012 Peyghan et al. 2013; Sari 1991; Sepahvand et al. 2013; Sepahvand and Sari 2010; Shahdadi et al. , 2014 Shinomiya and Sakai 2005; Stephenson 1945) .
body_text.section: Literature survey

body_text.text: Mollusks (Melvill 1897 (Melvill , 1898 (Melvill , 1899 Melvill and Standen 1901; Melvill 1904 Melvill , 1906 Amini Yekta et al. 2012; Hekmatara and Baladehi 2011; Hosseinzadeh et al. 2001) , echinoderms (Majid 2012) , and corals have been of interest to researchers (Kohan et al. 2012; Khaleghi and Owfi 2010; Salarzadeh et al. 2013; Benayahu and McFadden 2011; Maghsoudlou 2011; Namin and Van Ofwegen 2009; Samiei et al. 2013) .
body_text.section: Literature survey

body_text.text: Recently, identification of the marine free-living and parasitic worms was started, while some led to the description new species (Bonyadi Naiini 2008; Caira et al. 2011; Haseli et al. 2011; Maghsoudlou and Momtazi 2014; Maghsoudlou and Rahimian 2013, 2014; Maghsoudlou 2013; Khalili et al. 2009; Malek et al. 2010; Maleki et al. 2013; Moghadam and Haseli 2014; Naeini and Rahimian 2009; Polgar et al. 2009; Taheri and Foshtomi 2009; Yousefi et al. 2011) .
body_text.section: Literature survey

body_text.text: A limited number of researchers have studied more or less marine reptiles (Fadakar and Mazloomi 2013; Rezaie-Atagholipour et al. 2012) , tunicates, marine sponges, marine mammals (Owfi et al. 2013) , and benthic foraminifers (Cherif et al. 1997; Mooraki et al. 2013) .
body_text.section: Literature survey

body_text.text: At a glance, university theses among non-database sources have a significant role in producing biodiversity data, as 10,000 records or 40.3% of the total recorded data (Fig. 3) were extracted from 125 theses. About 22% of the data were extracted from articles (Fig. 3) . The high quantity of biodiversity data extracted from the university theses is firstly due to the larger number of published university theses 125compared to the JCR (85) and ISI 14articles and secondly due to high volume of biodiversity data presented in university theses. ROPME regional reports (seven available reports were reviewed in this study; Fig. 2 ) have a 24.5% contribution to biodiversity data production (Fig. 3) . The fewer number of ROPME reports compared to articles (Fig. 2) has produced more biodiversity data (Fig. 3) . This is due to the nature of the ROPME reports, which are the results of regional large-scale sea cruises that consequently produce high quantity data on marine organisms.
body_text.section: Literature survey

body_text.text: Globally, seven kingdoms (Archaea, Bacteria, Protozoa, Chromista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia) and 96 phyla were counted for all living organisms (Ruggiero et al. 2015) . For the marine environment, eight kingdoms (aforementioned kingdoms plus viruses) and over 90 phyla have been listed to date (Boxshall et al. 2016) . Our results show that researchers studied six of the seven kingdoms counted by Ruggiero et al. (2015) (except Archaea) that inhabit the Iranian waters of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman. At the phyla level, 47 of the 92 registered phyla on WoRMS (Boxshall et al. 2016) were listed for the study area. Animal phyla were studied due to the majority and variety of the university disciplines (i.e., fisheries, marine biology, zoology, etc.) interested in the study of animals compared to those interested in the study of other organisms (i.e., marine botany, bacteria, or fungi).
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases and research gaps

body_text.text: Within the kingdom Animalia, more than 25% of the distribution records in the study area belong to the phylum Arthropoda (Fig. 6) , which is not unexpected. Arthropods are the most diverse animal group on Earth, making up almost 66% of the known species on the planet, belonging to members of this phylum (Tittensor et al. 2010) . Easy taxonomic study of arthropods due to their hard body structure (which Fig. 10 Percent of synonymy in the different phyla extracted from non-database information sources. The greatest amount of synonymy was observed for Mollusca. The reported synonymy shows that more attention is needed in future biodiversity reports on these groups will lead to the reduction of fixing problems) compared with soft body invertebrates, which need complicated taxonomic works (e.g., marine worms, that also have fewer reported cases in the present study), is another reason for more generated data from marine arthropods and, in particular, crustaceans. However, even in well-studied animals such as crustaceans, there are still unknown subjects that require more attention, including taxonomic study on unknown/lesser known groups (i.e., amphipods, isopods, copepods, and ostracods), as well as resolving taxonomic uncertainties.
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases and research gaps

body_text.text: The lack of studies on invertebrates, particularly those playing an important role in marine ecosystems (e.g., sponges, marine tunicate, and worms), is remarkable. It is suggested that researchers should consider these invertebrates more in their future works on the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman.
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases and research gaps

body_text.text: Less than 1% of previous studies were conducted on marine bacteria and fungi (Fig. 6 ). Marine bacteria have particular importance in biological and chemical processes (i.e., microbial loop, biofouling, etc.) (Castro and Michael 2009) . Therefore, it is essential to study the diversity of these microorganisms in the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman, if we want to understand the food web structure and functions of the area. This will help to carry out applied and conceptual research towards solving many biohazard problems (e.g., biofouling).
body_text.section: Taxonomic composition of the reported cases and research gaps

body_text.text: Temporal trends of distribution records from non-database information sources shows an increasing rate of species reported from the region since 2000 (Fig. 4) . In recent years, an increased number of national taxonomists engaged in species descriptions may be the reason for this increasing trend. Globally, it has also been mentioned that the past decade has been the most productive period for marine species discovery. This may be due to the greater taxonomic effort, new technologies, exploration of new habitats and localities, use of molecular methods, or a combination of these factors (Appeltans et al. 2012) .
body_text.section: Temporal trends of biodiversity studies

body_text.text: Comparing OBIS datasets with non-database information sources (books, theses, research reports, and articles) showed that, although the number of OBIS records (34,430) is greater than non-database information sources (24,772), its taxon diversity is lower. Taxonomically, 424 species belonging to the 12 phyla and 318 genera were reported for Iran at OBIS datasets, compared to 2920 species belonging to 44 phyla and 1900 genera from the non-database information sources.
body_text.section: Species richness of the Iranian waters of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman

body_text.text: Consequently, 3364 valid species were extracted from all information sources (theses, books, reports, articles, OBIS, GBIF, museum archives). Wafar et al. (2011) , based on the relationship of fish species richness to total diversity, predicted 1424 species for the Iranian waters of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman. Therefore, our estimation of the species richness (3364 species) in this study is the first report that is based on the available information. The difference between the species richness found in this study with the predicted number by Wafar et al. (2011) reflects the inefficiency of the method based on the size of fish and total marine species diversity, an issue that was also emphasized by Wafar et al. (2011) . Species richness of the study area was believed to be more diverse than our estimation. Several lesser known/unknown taxa and marine bacteria are still waiting for identification. Furthermore, unknown deep-sea waters of the Gulf of Oman have the potential for great discoveries and describing new species (Richmond 2001) .
body_text.section: Species richness of the Iranian waters of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman

body_text.text: This review shows that the kingdoms of Animalia (2441 species) and Chromista (614 species) were the well-studied groups. Comparison of our results with Indian Ocean species richness stated by Wafar et al. (2011) shows almost the same trend (Fig. 11) . The kingdoms of Animalia and Chromista were the taxonomic groups that are well known for the western Indian Ocean (Richmond 2001) .
body_text.section: Species richness of the Iranian waters of the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman

body_text.text: The need to produce biodiversity data used in various research disciplines and conservation and development issues is increasing (Costello et al. 2013) . However, the source and reliability of the produced data have been a concern for scientists and decision-makers. The identification of biological specimens by non-experts and making decisions based on insufficient taxonomic evidence (e.g., photo or part of the specimen) are the main problems in producing reliable data. In addition, the lack of deposited specimens in museums eliminates the possibility of more detailed studies. Consequently, researchers have suggested additional practices (i.e., checking scientific name, identifier, coordinates, peer review process) to ensure satisfactory quality of the biodiversity data (Diepenbroek et al. 2014; Mayernik et al. 2015; Turnhout et al. 2016; Porter 1995; Costello et al. 2013 Costello et al. , 2015 . Although these studies have emphasized the need for quality control parameters in biodiversity reports, none of them has mentioned a method for determining the validity percent of published data. The present scoring method provides an integrative and applicable way for different users who want data with different quality; however, limitations in our scoring system can be expected. The peer review quality in all academic theses and research reports provided by different institutions is not the same; consequently, due to the lack of evaluation criteria, all theses from different universities have the same weight (scored 10 in Table 2 ) and all domestic research reports of institutions received the same weight (scored 4 in Table 2 ).
body_text.section: Biodiversity data quality control and calculating their validity percent

body_text.text: Due to high costs of marine studies, it is necessary that relevant marine authorities should consider more carefully the scientific and state-of-the-art principles in marine biodiversity research. This will prevent wasting of time and money and will produce more practical results when the generated data are utilized by other users (i.e., resource managers, monitoring of coastal ecosystems for natural and manmade changes, and other research disciplines). It is suggested that some national prerequisites are needed to produce accurate data on biological diversity before submission for publication. These include establishing a national marine biodiversity museum, training of more local taxonomists on using molecular marker tools (DNA barcoding) to identify any questionable species (i.e., cryptic species), having and a correct taxonomic identity to ensure practical achievements in other research disciplines (extraction of bioproducts, genetic manipulation to enhance product yield and biosafety). As stated by Costello and Wieczorek (2014) Bthe long-term availability of data is especially important in conservation science because field data can be costly to collect. In addition, historic data, especially on threatened species and their associated biota, become more valuable over time.^Therefore, establishing a national marine biodiversity database with collaborative partnerships of prominent domestic taxonomists is important. The national data may be published into the GBIF, OBIS, and PANGAEA international open-access databases through its regional nodes (including national biodiversity data centers). Fig. 11 Comparing the results on species diversity of the present study with that in the Indian Ocean (extracted from Wafar et al. 2011)
body_text.section: Recommendations

back_matter.text: Acknowledgements We appreciate the Iranian National Institute for Oceanography and Atmospheric Science (INIOAS), which provided the required grant (project grant number: 392-011-05). We thank the sincere cooperation of academic library administrators as well as various research centers. The authors also appreciate the respectful anonymous referees for their valuable comments, which made the article better. This article is dedicated to Professor Jamshid Darvish, a great man in the field of biodiversity studies in Iran, who passed away in recent days.

also suggests that 91% of the biodi-
versity data extracted from the books and national research
reports are a little valid (G2 in Table 4), which requires the
need for more attention in citing the data of such reports in
environmental conservation and management programs. At a
glance, 6% of the extracted biodiversity data from non-
database information sources have 75 to 100% credit (valid),
70% have 50 to 75% credit (semi-valid), 23% have 25 to 50%
credit (a little valid), and 0.9% have 0 to 25% credit (invalid).
On the other hand, the OBIS extracted data for Iran have no
invalid data, but 58 and 20% of its extracted data are semi-
valid and valid, respectively.
